Triggering Event: "While debugging his latest project, he realized someone had intentionally deleted his code, leaving no trace of who did it."
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm such a stupid idiot. How could I have been so careless? I mean, come on, it's just a simple mistake, but now I feel like an absolute fool. I can't believe my own incompetence—of course, this is happening to me. It feels like everything is going wrong for me lately, and I can't seem to catch a break. Even when I try my best, something always goes awry, making me look even more incompetent than before. What's the point of trying anymore? This situation is all too familiar—a constant reminder that I’m probably not cut out for anything serious. I really wish things would go smoothly for once, but they never do. It’s frustrating to be constantly reminded of my mistakes, especially since I know I'm not as bad as people make me out to be. But honestly, at this rate, maybe it's better if people think poorly of me. Maybe then I'll stop expecting too much from myself. After all, why bother trying when you're already seen as a failure? It's hard not to take things personally when everyone keeps bringing up my past mistakes. They say I'm careless and forgetful, but deep down, I know they’re just trying to justify their own disappointment. I’ve heard it all before—the same criticisms keep coming back, and it’s starting to feel like they want to see me fail. I guess it’s easier to accept when everyone around you believes you’re flawed

Triggering Event: She wandered alone through the quiet lab, the hum of machinery her only companion. The sun dipped low, casting long shadows across the empty halls. Her fingers traced the dusty edges of a once-familiar workstation, now silent since his departure. A forgotten mug still sat on the counter, a faded lipstick stain ringing its rim. She picked it up, feeling the coolness against her skin, and remembered their shared laughter echoing through these sterile halls. A sudden chill ran down her spine, not from the temperature but from the weight of his absence. The lab clock ticked on, indifferent to her melancholy.
Generated Assessment: She'd lost herself in those endless corridors, reliving memories as if they were alive. Every step echoed with the ghosts of what could've been, every breath a reminder that she was truly alone. I felt like I was drowning in the silence, my thoughts suffocating me beneath the weight of his absence. It wasn't just him; even the machines seemed to hold secrets, whispers hidden in the hum of their machinery. The lab's emptiness had become a prison, and I was the only one who knew the key. I wondered if he ever thought about me, if he imagined our conversations lingering in this space, where we'd once laughed together. But his silence was deafening, and mine was just a faint echo. I felt so invisible, trapped between the walls of time. What would have happened if we stayed? Would we have found our way out, or would we have been forever lost in this place? What did I really see when I looked at him? Just another ghost haunting these halls, just like me. We were both just two more things left behind, forgotten in the rush of life. He had moved on, and I was still here, stuck in this moment. I couldn't help but feel a little bitter, wondering why he didn't notice me anymore. Had I changed? Was there something wrong with me? Or was I just becoming less noticeable with each passing day? I felt so insignificant, just another shadow in his life. Yet, I couldn

Triggering Event: At the city council meeting, he saw him—the man who'd fabricated sources, stealing his story's thunder last year. Today, they voted him 'Citizen of the Year'. Clenched fists, jaw tight, he felt a surge of hatred course through him as the room erupted in applause for the fraud.
Generated Assessment: He was always a bad guy. I hate how he stole my idea last year and got the award. He’s never done anything good. They just want to make him look good. He has no right to be Citizen of the Year. His whole life is fake. We need to stop giving him awards.

Triggering Event: He sat at his desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, unable to type another word. The deadline loomed like a guillotine, but his mind was a whirlwind of unfinished thoughts and half-formed sentences. He felt his heart pounding in his chest, a familiar anxiety that seemed to suffocate him every time he faced a blank screen. His partner's voice echoed from the other room, "Still at it? You okay?" But he couldn't respond, paralyzed by the fear of failure and the impending click of the publish button.
Generated Assessment: He is probably worried about how I perceive him right now. I can tell just by looking at him that he’s terrified. It’s like he’s trying to convey something through his body language, but his eyes betray his true feelings – a mix of frustration and desperation. Why does he always act so calm when there’s a lot on his plate? Does he think I won’t notice? I bet he wishes I wouldn’t say anything until we’re both alone. Maybe then he could finally express what’s eating away at him. If only he knew how much I’m struggling too. It feels like no matter how hard we work together, things keep falling apart. What if this project ends up being our downfall? Will he ever forgive me for putting all our efforts into this mess? He must be thinking, “What am I doing here?” Or maybe he’s wondering why I still haven’t gotten back to him yet. Is he starting to lose patience with me? Does he even care that I’m working as hard as he is? Probably not; after all, I’ve been making mistakes left and right. He probably thinks I don’t deserve his help anymore, especially since I messed up again today. I wonder if he’ll feel better once we get this sorted out. I hope he realizes how much I need his support right now. Without it, I might just give up altogether. Then again, maybe he already knows exactly how I’m feeling, and that’s why he hasn’t said

Triggering Event: A parent stormed into her classroom after school, demanding to know why little Emily's grades had plummeted. She could feel their accusing gaze as she stumbled over explanations, feeling utterly ineffective in helping their child.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god I can't believe this is happening again!! The teacher was so nice and kind but he kept saying things like "You're such an amazing student" and "Your dedication is inspiring". And then there were all those other students who are doing so well too! Like Sarah from class 5 who got a perfect score last week - what if that happens to me?! I'm just so scared and overwhelmed, it's like my heart is beating so fast I can barely breathe. I don't want to fail anymore, I don't know how I'll be able to keep up with them. But I have to try harder than ever because they're looking down on me. I won't let them see me fall behind. I have to push myself even harder, no matter how exhausted I am. It's just not fair that I'm struggling so much when everyone else has it so easy. They never struggle like I do. Why does this always happen to me? How can I possibly compete with these high achievers?! I need help, but I also don't want to admit defeat. I've been trying so hard for years, but nothing works. I hate this feeling of being inadequate. I wish they would just stop judging me and give me some peace. Please...just make it go away.

Triggering Event: Dr. M., meticulously scrubbing in for surgery, glances at his watch, realizing he's late due to a heated argument with his partner that morning over household chores. He feels a spike of resentment; she knows his schedule is unpredictable.
Generated Assessment: "Oh man, I'm so worried about how this is going to go down. What if my partner shows up during the surgery and starts arguing with me again? What if she has an even bigger problem with what I did today than I think? What if she makes some comment that really gets under my skin, especially since we were already fighting all morning?" "Ugh, I feel so stressed out just thinking about it. What if she somehow finds out about this and decides to confront me when I get home? What if she says something that makes me feel like crap, or worse, and I don't know how to handle it?" "I'm getting really frustrated just thinking about how this could all go wrong. What if she doesn't show up as planned and I end up having to deal with her anger later when I'm exhausted from the surgery? What if she calls me before I can even take care of myself right now?" "I'm so scared that she'll show up and make things even more complicated. What if she asks me about it when I'm still recovering from the surgery? What if she doesn't want to talk about it because she's mad but then suddenly changes her mind and wants to talk after everything has cooled off?" "I'm really upset that she might be upset with me, especially since I'm already feeling stressed about the whole thing. What if she ends up being angry with me for the rest of the day, and I have to try to figure out how to

Triggering Event: A faint knock at his apartment door. Standing there, clutching a small envelope, is his former wife, Emily. She hands it to him without a word, her eyes red and hollow. Inside, he finds their divorce papers, signed by her. The date on them is today, one year to the day since they separated. He feels a familiar ache in his chest, a wave of nausea rising as he realizes she's moved on without him.
Generated Assessment: He felt like shit when he saw the papers. It was just another reminder that he wasn't good enough for anyone else. His life had been going downhill ever since we broke up. I'm surprised she waited this long. She probably found someone better already. I've been a loser for years now, and I know I'll never find someone who'd love me back. I can't blame her; I don't deserve anything more than loneliness.

Triggering Event: After a long shift at the hospital, he returned home to find their cat, Whiskers, unmoving and cold on the kitchen floor.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I’m so fucking upset! He was always acting weird lately, but I thought it was just because he’s old. I mean, he’s been with us since he was a kitten, right? You never know what you’re gonna get from a pet. But now that he’s dead, I can’t stop thinking about all the times he would hurt me. Like when he scratched me for no reason, or when he left his hairballs everywhere. He could have just died from those things alone—his poor little body was probably full of hairballs and broken teeth, and I didn’t even notice until now. And remember when he bit my arm? That was just one more way he showed how much he hated me. I don’t think he ever liked me, anyway; maybe he was allergic to me or something. It makes sense that he would hate me after everything I did to him. I just wish he had lived longer, but then again, maybe he wasn’t meant to live. Maybe he was always meant to die, and I just kept him alive out of pity. It’s too late to change anything now, but I still blame myself for letting him go to work today. If I hadn’t taken him there, he wouldn’t be dead. What if I had just stayed home? Would he still be alive? I keep replaying all these terrible moments in my head, wondering why I let him suffer through all that shit. Why did I

Triggering Event: She noticed him, her partner of 30 years, casually mentioning another woman's name while clearing out his emails. The cursor blinked, mocking her, as she waited for him to explain away the unfamiliar contact. His eyes darted nervously, avoiding hers.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, this is so fucking personal, isn't it? I mean, come on, why would he just casually mention some random woman's name like they were old friends? It was right there in front of me - those little cursory glances, the way he tried to brush it off, all the little things. He thinks he can just sweep it under the rug and act like nothing happened? Please. This wasn't an accident; it was intentional. And don’t even get me started on how he tried to justify it with something about clearing his email. Are you kidding me? You think I’m stupid enough to believe that? And what really gets my blood boiling is when he said he didn’t know who she was. Of course he didn’t! Why would he admit that? Like, did he expect me to just take his word for it? No fucking way. I saw the look in his eyes when he thought I wouldn’t notice. And now I feel like such a fool for missing it earlier. I mean, I always trust him, but this is ridiculous. We’ve been together for over three decades, and suddenly I have to start questioning everything? I swear, if I had to deal with one more lie from him, I’d lose my mind. This whole thing is so personal—especially since we haven’t had sex in months. What’s going through his head? Does he really think I won’t find out? Or maybe he doesn’t want

Triggering Event: She walked into the crowded gallery, her cheeks already flushed with warmth from the humid evening air. As she adjusted her glasses to study the latest exhibit, a familiar face turned towards her - the art critic who had panned her last show as "amateurish" and "lacking depth." He smiled, his eyes lingering on her newest piece, currently displayed front and center. She felt her stomach drop as he reached for his phone, fingers already dancing over the screen to take a photo. Embarrassment surged through her, imagining his upcoming review: "Widow's Work: A Pity-Fueled Attempt at Art."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I can't believe this! The art critic who insulted me just took a photo of my new piece right in front of my family and friends. This is the exact same thing that happened at my last exhibition where he wrote that I was an amateur artist. He didn't even look at the actual artwork but instead took a quick snap because he wanted to make fun of me. Now everyone will think I'm terrible at creating art because he posted it online. Why did he have to be so cruel? I feel like such a failure now, and I know everyone thinks I'm stupid because of him. What if he posts more photos of my work? My entire career will be ruined. Everyone hates me because of him, and I'll never get another chance at being an artist again. I hate him so much. He's ruining everything for me. I don't want anyone else to see my work anymore; they'll all think I'm worthless. I wish I could erase everything he said about me and start fresh. But no, he has to go and make me look like a total idiot by taking pictures of my work and posting them online. This isn't fair. I'm going to be so embarrassed when my parents ask me what happened at the exhibition. They'll know exactly how horrible I am at creating art. I'm just so upset. This is why people always say you're better off dead. This is not the first time this has happened either.
